scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Live register'd upon our brazen tombs

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: And then grace us in the disgrace of death;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: When, spite of cormorant devouring Time,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: The endeavor of this present breath may buy

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: And make us heirs of all eternity.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Therefore, brave conquerors,--for so you are,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That war against your own affections

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: And the huge army of the world's desires,--

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Our court shall be a little Academe,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Still and contemplative in living art.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: You three, Biron, Dumain, and Longaville,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Have sworn for three years' term to live with me

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: My fellow-scholars, and to keep those statutes

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That are recorded in this schedule here:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Your oaths are pass'd; and now subscribe your names,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That his own hand may strike his honour down

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That violates the smallest branch herein:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: If you are arm'd to do as sworn to do,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: I am resolved; 'tis but a three years' fast:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: The mind shall banquet, though the body pine:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: My loving lord, Dumain is mortified:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: The grosser manner of these world's delights

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: With all these living in philosophy.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: I can but say their protestation over;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: That is, to live and study here three years.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: But there are other strict observances;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: As, not to see a woman in that term,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Which I hope well is not enrolled there;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And one day in a week to touch no food

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And but one meal on every day beside,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: The which I hope is not enrolled there;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And then, to sleep but three hours in the night,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And not be seen to wink of all the day--

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: When I was wont to think no harm all night

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And make a dark night too of half the day--

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Which I hope well is not enrolled there:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Your oath is pass'd to pass away from these.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: I only swore to study with your grace

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And stay here in your court for three years' space.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: You swore to that, Biron, and to the rest.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: What is the end of study? let me know.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Why, that to know, which else we should not know.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Things hid and barr'd, you mean, from common sense?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Ay, that is study's godlike recompense.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Come on, then; I will swear to study so,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: To know the thing I am forbid to know:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: As thus,--to study where I well may dine,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: When I to feast expressly am forbid;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Or study where to meet some mistress fine,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: When mistresses from common sense are hid;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Or, having sworn too hard a keeping oath,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Study to break it and not break my troth.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: If study's gain be thus and this be so,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Study knows that which yet it doth not know:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Swear me to this, and I will ne'er say no.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: These be the stops that hinder study quite

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: And train our intellects to vain delight.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Why, all delights are vain; but that most vain,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Which with pain purchased doth inherit pain:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: As, painfully to pore upon a book

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: To seek the light of truth; while truth the while

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Light seeking light doth light of light beguile:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: So, ere you find where light in darkness lies,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Study me how to please the eye indeed

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: By fixing it upon a fairer eye,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And give him light that it was blinded by.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Study is like the heaven's glorious sun

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: That will not be deep-search'd with saucy looks:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Small have continual plodders ever won

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Save base authority from others' books

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: That give a name to every fixed star

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Have no more profit of their shining nights

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Than those that walk and wot not what they are.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Too much to know is to know nought but fame;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And every godfather can give a name.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: How well he's read, to reason against reading!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: He weeds the corn and still lets grow the weeding.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: How follows that?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Fit in his place and time.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DUMAIN
line: In reason nothing.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Something then in rhyme.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Biron is like an envious sneaping frost,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Well, say I am; why should proud summer boast

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Before the birds have any cause to sing?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Why should I joy in any abortive birth?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: At Christmas I no more desire a rose

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled mirth;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: But like of each thing that in season grows.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: So you, to study now it is too late,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Climb o'er the house to unlock the little gate.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Well, sit you out: go home, Biron: adieu.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: No, my good lord; I have sworn to stay with you:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And though I have for barbarism spoke more

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Than for that angel knowledge you can say,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Yet confident I'll keep what I have swore

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And bide the penance of each three years' day.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Give me the paper; let me read the same;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And to the strict'st decrees I'll write my name.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Reads  'Item, That no woman shall come within a

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: mile of my court:' Hath this been proclaimed?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Four days ago.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Let's see the penalty.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: 'On pain of losing her tongue.' Who devised this penalty?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Marry, that did I.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Sweet lord, and why?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: A dangerous law against gentility!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: 'Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: within the term of three years, he shall endure such

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: public shame as the rest of the court can possibly devise.'

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: This article, my liege, yourself must break;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: For well you know here comes in embassy

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: The French king's daughter with yourself to speak--

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: A maid of grace and complete majesty--

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: About surrender up of Aquitaine

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: To her decrepit, sick and bedrid father:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Therefore this article is made in vain,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Or vainly comes the admired princess hither.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: So study evermore is overshot:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: While it doth study to have what it would

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: It doth forget to do the thing it should,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: 'Tis won as towns with fire, so won, so lost.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: We must of force dispense with this decree;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: She must lie here on mere necessity.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Necessity will make us all forsworn

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Three thousand times within this three years' space;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: For every man with his affects is born,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Not by might master'd but by special grace:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: If I break faith, this word shall speak for me;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: I am forsworn on 'mere necessity.'

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: So to the laws at large I write my name:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: And he that breaks them in the least degree

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Stands in attainder of eternal shame:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Suggestions are to other as to me;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: But I believe, although I seem so loath,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: I am the last that will last keep his oath.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: But is there no quick recreation granted?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: With a refined traveller of Spain;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: A man in all the world's new fashion planted,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: One whom the music of his own vain tongue

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: A man of complements, whom right and wrong

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: Have chose as umpire of their mutiny:

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: This child of fancy, that Armado hight,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: For interim to our studies shall relate

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: In high-born words the worth of many a knight

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: How you delight, my lords, I know not, I;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: But, I protest, I love to hear him lie

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Armado is a most illustrious wight,

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport;

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: And so to study, three years is but short.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: Which is the duke's own person?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: This, fellow: what wouldst?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: grace's tharborough: but I would see his own person

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: in flesh and blood.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: This is he.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: Signior Arme--Arme--commends you. There's villany

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: DULL
line: abroad: this letter will tell you more.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: COSTARD
line: Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: FERDINAND
line: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: A high hope for a low heaven: God grant us patience!

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: To hear? or forbear laughing?

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or to

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: forbear both.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: BIRON
line: climb in the merriness.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: COSTARD
line: The matter is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenetta.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.
speaker: COSTARD
line: The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

scene: SCENE I.  The king of Navarre's park.

line: A mess of Russians left us but of late.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: How, madam! Russians!

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Ay, in truth, my lord;

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord:

speaker: ROSALINE
line: My lady, to the manner of the days,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: In courtesy gives undeserving praise.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: We four indeed confronted were with four

speaker: ROSALINE
line: In Russian habit: here they stay'd an hour,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: And talk'd apace; and in that hour, my lord,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: They did not bless us with one happy word.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: I dare not call them fools; but this I think,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

speaker: BIRON
line: This jest is dry to me. Fair gentle sweet,

speaker: BIRON
line: Your wit makes wise things foolish: when we greet,

speaker: BIRON
line: With eyes best seeing, heaven's fiery eye,

speaker: BIRON
line: By light we lose light: your capacity

speaker: BIRON
line: Is of that nature that to your huge store

speaker: BIRON
line: Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye,--

speaker: BIRON
line: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: But that you take what doth to you belong,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

speaker: BIRON
line: O, I am yours, and all that I possess!

speaker: ROSALINE
line: All the fool mine?

speaker: BIRON
line: I cannot give you less.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Which of the vizards was it that you wore?

speaker: BIRON
line: Where? when? what vizard? why demand you this?

speaker: ROSALINE
line: There, then, that vizard; that superfluous case

speaker: ROSALINE
line: That hid the worse and show'd the better face.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: We are descried; they'll mock us now downright.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Amazed, my lord? why looks your highness sad?

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Help, hold his brows! he'll swoon! Why look you pale?

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Sea-sick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

speaker: BIRON
line: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury.

speaker: BIRON
line: Can any face of brass hold longer out?

speaker: BIRON
line: Here stand I lady, dart thy skill at me;

speaker: BIRON
line: Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout;

speaker: BIRON
line: Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance;

speaker: BIRON
line: Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit;

speaker: BIRON
line: And I will wish thee never more to dance,

speaker: BIRON
line: Nor never more in Russian habit wait.

speaker: BIRON
line: O, never will I trust to speeches penn'd,

speaker: BIRON
line: Nor to the motion of a schoolboy's tongue,

speaker: BIRON
line: Nor never come in vizard to my friend,

speaker: BIRON
line: Nor woo in rhyme, like a blind harper's song!

speaker: BIRON
line: Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise,

speaker: BIRON
line: Three-piled hyperboles, spruce affectation,

speaker: BIRON
line: Figures pedantical; these summer-flies

speaker: BIRON
line: Have blown me full of maggot ostentation:

speaker: BIRON
line: I do forswear them; and I here protest,

speaker: BIRON
line: By this white glove;--how white the hand, God knows!--

speaker: BIRON
line: Henceforth my wooing mind shall be express'd

speaker: BIRON
line: In russet yeas and honest kersey noes:

speaker: BIRON
line: And, to begin, wench,--so God help me, la!--

speaker: BIRON
line: My love to thee is sound, sans crack or flaw.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Sans sans, I pray you.

speaker: BIRON
line: Yet I have a trick

speaker: BIRON
line: Of the old rage: bear with me, I am sick;

speaker: BIRON
line: I'll leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see:

speaker: BIRON
line: Write, 'Lord have mercy on us' on those three;

speaker: BIRON
line: They are infected; in their hearts it lies;

speaker: BIRON
line: They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes;

speaker: BIRON
line: These lords are visited; you are not free,

speaker: BIRON
line: For the Lord's tokens on you do I see.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

speaker: BIRON
line: Our states are forfeit: seek not to undo us.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: It is not so; for how can this be true,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: That you stand forfeit, being those that sue?

speaker: BIRON
line: Peace! for I will not have to do with you.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

speaker: BIRON
line: Speak for yourselves; my wit is at an end.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Some fair excuse.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: The fairest is confession.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Were not you here but even now disguised?

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Madam, I was.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: And were you well advised?

speaker: FERDINAND
line: I was, fair madam.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: When you then were here,

speaker: PRINCESS
line: What did you whisper in your lady's ear?

speaker: FERDINAND
line: That more than all the world I did respect her.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Upon mine honour, no.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Peace, peace! forbear:

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Despise me, when I break this oath of mine.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: I will: and therefore keep it. Rosaline,

speaker: PRINCESS
line: What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear

speaker: ROSALINE
line: As precious eyesight, and did value me

speaker: ROSALINE
line: Above this world; adding thereto moreover

speaker: ROSALINE
line: That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: God give thee joy of him! the noble lord

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Most honourably doth unhold his word.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: What mean you, madam? by my life, my troth,

speaker: FERDINAND
line: I never swore this lady such an oath.

speaker: ROSALINE
line: By heaven, you did; and to confirm it plain,

speaker: ROSALINE
line: You gave me this: but take it, sir, again.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: My faith and this the princess I did give:

speaker: FERDINAND
line: I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear;

speaker: PRINCESS
line: And Lord Biron, I thank him, is my dear.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: What, will you have me, or your pearl again?

speaker: BIRON
line: Neither of either; I remit both twain.

speaker: BIRON
line: I see the trick on't: here was a consent,

speaker: BIRON
line: Knowing aforehand of our merriment,

speaker: BIRON
line: To dash it like a Christmas comedy:

speaker: BIRON
line: Some carry-tale, some please-man, some slight zany,

speaker: BIRON
line: Some mumble-news, some trencher-knight, some Dick,

speaker: BIRON
line: That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick

speaker: BIRON
line: To make my lady laugh when she's disposed,

speaker: BIRON
line: Told our intents before; which once disclosed,

speaker: BIRON
line: The ladies did change favours: and then we,

speaker: BIRON
line: Following the signs, woo'd but the sign of she.

speaker: BIRON
line: Now, to our perjury to add more terror,

speaker: BIRON
line: We are again forsworn, in will and error.

speaker: BIRON
line: Much upon this it is: and might not you

speaker: BIRON
line: Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue?

speaker: BIRON
line: Do not you know my lady's foot by the squier,

speaker: BIRON
line: And laugh upon the apple of her eye?

speaker: BIRON
line: And stand between her back, sir, and the fire,

speaker: BIRON
line: Holding a trencher, jesting merrily?

speaker: BIRON
line: You put our page out: go, you are allow'd;

speaker: BIRON
line: Die when you will, a smock shall be your shroud.

speaker: BIRON
line: You leer upon me, do you? there's an eye

speaker: BIRON
line: Wounds like a leaden sword.

speaker: BOYET
line: Full merrily

speaker: BOYET
line: Hath this brave manage, this career, been run.

speaker: BIRON
line: Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace! I have done.

speaker: BIRON
line: Welcome, pure wit! thou partest a fair fray.

speaker: COSTARD
line: O Lord, sir, they would know

speaker: COSTARD
line: Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

speaker: BIRON
line: What, are there but three?

speaker: COSTARD
line: No, sir; but it is vara fine,

speaker: COSTARD
line: For every one pursents three.

speaker: BIRON
line: And three times thrice is nine.

speaker: COSTARD
line: Not so, sir; under correction, sir; I hope it is not so.

speaker: COSTARD
line: You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir we know

speaker: COSTARD
line: what we know:

speaker: COSTARD
line: I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir,--

speaker: BIRON
line: Is not nine.

speaker: COSTARD
line: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount.

speaker: BIRON
line: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

speaker: COSTARD
line: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living

speaker: COSTARD
line: by reckoning, sir.

speaker: BIRON
line: How much is it?

speaker: COSTARD
line: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors,

speaker: COSTARD
line: sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount: for mine

speaker: COSTARD
line: own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one man

speaker: COSTARD
line: in one poor man, Pompion the Great, sir.

speaker: BIRON
line: Art thou one of the Worthies?

speaker: COSTARD
line: It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompion the

speaker: COSTARD
line: Great: for mine own part, I know not the degree of

speaker: COSTARD
line: the Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

speaker: BIRON
line: Go, bid them prepare.

speaker: COSTARD
line: We will turn it finely off, sir; we will take

speaker: COSTARD
line: some care.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Biron, they will shame us: let them not approach.

speaker: BIRON
line: We are shame-proof, my lord: and tis some policy

speaker: BIRON
line: To have one show worse than the king's and his company.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: I say they shall not come.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Nay, my good lord, let me o'errule you now:

speaker: PRINCESS
line: That sport best pleases that doth least know how:

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Where zeal strives to content, and the contents

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Dies in the zeal of that which it presents:

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Their form confounded makes most form in mirth,

speaker: PRINCESS
line: When great things labouring perish in their birth.

speaker: BIRON
line: A right description of our sport, my lord.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: sweet breath as will utter a brace of words.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Doth this man serve God?

speaker: BIRON
line: Why ask you?

speaker: PRINCESS
line: He speaks not like a man of God's making.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch; for,

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: fantastical; too, too vain, too too vain: but we

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: will put it, as they say, to fortuna de la guerra.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: I wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement!

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies. He

speaker: FERDINAND
line: presents Hector of Troy; the swain, Pompey the

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Great; the parish curate, Alexander; Armado's page,

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Hercules; the pedant, Judas Maccabaeus: And if

speaker: FERDINAND
line: these four Worthies in their first show thrive,

speaker: FERDINAND
line: These four will change habits, and present the other five.

speaker: BIRON
line: There is five in the first show.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: You are deceived; 'tis not so.

speaker: BIRON
line: The pedant, the braggart, the hedge-priest, the fool

speaker: BIRON
line: and the boy:--

speaker: BIRON
line: Abate throw at novum, and the whole world again

speaker: BIRON
line: Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vein.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: The ship is under sail, and here she comes amain.

speaker: COSTARD
line: I Pompey am,--

speaker: BOYET
line: You lie, you are not he.

speaker: COSTARD
line: I Pompey am,--

speaker: BOYET
line: With libbard's head on knee.

speaker: BIRON
line: Well said, old mocker: I must needs be friends

speaker: BIRON
line: with thee.

speaker: COSTARD
line: I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the Big--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: The Great.

speaker: COSTARD
line: It is, 'Great,' sir:--

speaker: COSTARD
line: Pompey surnamed the Great;

speaker: COSTARD
line: That oft in field, with targe and shield, did make

speaker: COSTARD
line: my foe to sweat:

speaker: COSTARD
line: And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance,

speaker: COSTARD
line: And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France,

speaker: COSTARD
line: If your ladyship would say, 'Thanks, Pompey,' I had done.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Great thanks, great Pompey.

speaker: COSTARD
line: 'Tis not so much worth; but I hope I was perfect: I

speaker: COSTARD
line: made a little fault in 'Great.'

speaker: BIRON
line: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: When in the world I lived, I was the world's

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: commander;

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: By east, west, north, and south, I spread my

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: conquering might:

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander,--

speaker: BOYET
line: Your nose says, no, you are not for it stands too right.

speaker: BIRON
line: Your nose smells 'no' in this, most tender-smelling knight.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: The conqueror is dismay'd. Proceed, good Alexander.

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: When in the world I lived, I was the world's

speaker: SIR NATHANIEL
line: commander,--

speaker: BOYET
line: Most true, 'tis right; you were so, Alisander.

speaker: BIRON
line: Pompey the Great,--

speaker: COSTARD
line: Your servant, and Costard.

speaker: BIRON
line: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

speaker: COSTARD
line: To SIR NATHANIEL  O, sir, you have overthrown

speaker: COSTARD
line: Alisander the conqueror! You will be scraped out of

speaker: COSTARD
line: the painted cloth for this: your lion, that holds

speaker: COSTARD
line: his poll-axe sitting on a close-stool, will be given

speaker: COSTARD
line: to Ajax: he will be the ninth Worthy. A conqueror,

speaker: COSTARD
line: and afeard to speak! run away for shame, Alisander.

speaker: COSTARD
line: There, an't shall please you; a foolish mild man; an

speaker: COSTARD
line: honest man, look you, and soon dashed. He is a

speaker: COSTARD
line: marvellous good neighbour, faith, and a very good

speaker: COSTARD
line: bowler: but, for Alisander,--alas, you see how

speaker: COSTARD
line: 'tis,--a little o'erparted. But there are Worthies

speaker: COSTARD
line: a-coming will speak their mind in some other sort.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Great Hercules is presented by this imp,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Whose club kill'd Cerberus, that three-headed canis;

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Quoniam he seemeth in minority,

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Ergo I come with this apology.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Judas I am,--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: A Judas!

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Not Iscariot, sir.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Judas I am, ycliped Maccabaeus.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Judas Maccabaeus clipt is plain Judas.

speaker: BIRON
line: A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas?

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Judas I am,--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: The more shame for you, Judas.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: What mean you, sir?

speaker: BOYET
line: To make Judas hang himself.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: Begin, sir; you are my elder.

speaker: BIRON
line: Well followed: Judas was hanged on an elder.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: I will not be put out of countenance.

speaker: BIRON
line: Because thou hast no face.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: What is this?

speaker: BOYET
line: A cittern-head.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: The head of a bodkin.

speaker: BIRON
line: A Death's face in a ring.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

speaker: BOYET
line: The pommel of Caesar's falchion.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: The carved-bone face on a flask.

speaker: BIRON
line: Saint George's half-cheek in a brooch.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

speaker: BIRON
line: Ay, and worn in the cap of a tooth-drawer.

speaker: BIRON
line: And now forward; for we have put thee in countenance.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: You have put me out of countenance.

speaker: BIRON
line: False; we have given thee faces.

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: But you have out-faced them all.

speaker: BIRON
line: An thou wert a lion, we would do so.

speaker: BOYET
line: Therefore, as he is an ass, let him go.

speaker: BOYET
line: And so adieu, sweet Jude! nay, why dost thou stay?

speaker: DUMAIN
line: For the latter end of his name.

speaker: BIRON
line: For the ass to the Jude; give it him:--Jud-as, away!

speaker: HOLOFERNES
line: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

speaker: BOYET
line: A light for Monsieur Judas! it grows dark, he may stumble.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Alas, poor Maccabaeus, how hath he been baited!

speaker: BIRON
line: Hide thy head, Achilles: here comes Hector in arms.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

speaker: FERDINAND
line: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

speaker: BOYET
line: But is this Hector?

speaker: FERDINAND
line: I think Hector was not so clean-timbered.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: His leg is too big for Hector's.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: More calf, certain.

speaker: BOYET
line: No; he is best endued in the small.

speaker: BIRON
line: This cannot be Hector.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: He's a god or a painter; for he makes faces.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty,

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Gave Hector a gift,--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: A gilt nutmeg.

speaker: BIRON
line: A lemon.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: Stuck with cloves.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: No, cloven.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Peace!--

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion;

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: A man so breathed, that certain he would fight; yea

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: From morn till night, out of his pavilion.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: I am that flower,--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: That mint.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: That columbine.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

speaker: LONGAVILLE
line: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against Hector.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Ay, and Hector's a greyhound.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: The sweet war-man is dead and rotten; sweet chucks,

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: beat not the bones of the buried: when he breathed,

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: he was a man. But I will forward with my device.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.

speaker: PRINCESS
line: Speak, brave Hector: we are much delighted.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: I do adore thy sweet grace's slipper.

speaker: BOYET
line: Aside to DUMAIN  Loves her by the foot,--

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Aside to BOYET  He may not by the yard.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: This Hector far surmounted Hannibal,--

speaker: COSTARD
line: The party is gone, fellow Hector, she is gone; she

speaker: COSTARD
line: is two months on her way.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: What meanest thou?

speaker: COSTARD
line: Faith, unless you play the honest Troyan, the poor

speaker: COSTARD
line: wench is cast away: she's quick; the child brags in

speaker: COSTARD
line: her belly already: tis yours.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? thou shalt

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: die.

speaker: COSTARD
line: Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that is

speaker: COSTARD
line: quick by him and hanged for Pompey that is dead by

speaker: COSTARD
line: him.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Most rare Pompey!

speaker: BOYET
line: Renowned Pompey!

speaker: BIRON
line: Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey!

speaker: BIRON
line: Pompey the Huge!

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Hector trembles.

speaker: BIRON
line: Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! stir them

speaker: BIRON
line: on! stir them on!

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Hector will challenge him.

speaker: BIRON
line: Ay, if a' have no man's blood in's belly than will

speaker: BIRON
line: sup a flea.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

speaker: COSTARD
line: I will not fight with a pole, like a northern man:

speaker: COSTARD
line: I'll slash; I'll do it by the sword. I bepray you,

speaker: COSTARD
line: let me borrow my arms again.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Room for the incensed Worthies!

speaker: COSTARD
line: I'll do it in my shirt.

speaker: DUMAIN
line: Most resolute Pompey!

speaker: MOTH
line: Master, let me take you a buttonhole lower. Do you

speaker: MOTH
line: not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean

speaker: MOTH
line: you? You will lose your reputation.

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me; I will not combat

speaker: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO
line: in my shirt.

speaker: DUMAIN

line: And what in us hath seem'd ridiculous,--

speaker: BIRON
line: As love is full of unbefitting strains,

speaker: BIRON
line: All wanton as a child, skipping and vain,

speaker: BIRON
line: Form'd by the eye and therefore, like the eye,

line: Full of strange shapes, of habits and of forms,

speaker: BIRON
line: Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll

line: Put on by us, if, in your heavenly eyes,

line: Have misbecomed our oaths and gravities,

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
line: Suggested us to make. Therefore, ladies,

speaker: BIRON
line: Our love being yours, the error that love makes

speaker: BIRON
line: Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false,

speaker: BIRON
line: By being once false for ever to be true

speaker: BIRON
line: To those that make us both,--fair ladies, you:

speaker: BIRON

speaker: BIRON
